October 1, 195>2
Dear Allen:
There seems to be some confusion and doubt floating
around as to Tom Rishworth's worth to educational
radio now that "he is rendered impotent by the strain
of emotional crises." I would like to go on record
in support of Tom and state my views and reasons why
I think, along with others, that Tom is entirely
capable of maintaining and upholding any educational
radio office offered him.
In doing so, perhaps a brief sketch of the recent
upheaval at Radio House is in order.
The issue was so clouded that not even Tom, as I see
it, can be exactly clear on what happened. However,
two points do seem clear: two psycopathic personali¬
ties were involved—one a woman in the script office,
the other a man in the general office. Both people
played heavily on Tom's bigheartedness to hold their
jobs. That Tom should have fired them, or at least
one of them, is probably without question. The woman
in the script office had tried to undermine Tony
Lumphin, Elithe Beale and A1 Chapman. They left their
jobs before she "got" them. Hers is a feeling of "to
keep my job secure, I've got to discredit the top man."
It was a challenge to Tom to get along with her.
Examine her case in this light. After complete re¬
writing at times by Gale Adkins, at times by Tom, other
times by me, some of her "scripts" won national re¬
cognition—in her name. Neither the Radio Committee
nor the Presidents Office could fully understand firing
a woman with such nationally recognized ability. But
ask Gale Adkins why he thinks the scripts of "Leather-
britches" looked good to the Peabody people, or check
v/ith A1 Chapman on the background of "Healthy Living
In Our Country." These are but two examples! So,
Tom's decision was that if he couldn't have support
in firing her, he would get along with her. And for
six years he didl In those six years he made Radio
House a nationally known and respected institution.
The situation which made it necessary for Tom to
compromise with, instead of getting rid of this woman,
is a University of Texas situation; not a Tom Rishworth
situation. To support this point I merely ask you to
answer the question: Why was the Radio Committee, in
the period from May to September of this year, unable
to find anyone willing to step into the untenable
situation there?
